Urgently hiring forWe are looking for a Java / Kafka Consultant. This is a 6-month remote contract position, with an urgent need for an offshore resource based in India.Job Title: Java / Kafka ConsultantLocation: Remote in IndiaDuration: 6+ months contractRole Description:The role requires a minimum of four years of experience in setting up Kafka-based big data solutions using Kafka, Spark, and Scala.Strong expertise in Kafka architecture and managing single and multi-node Kafka clusters on VMs, Docker, and Kubernetes is essential.Experience with Confluent Platform is a must, along with a deep understanding of Kafka Producer/Consumer APIs, Stream Processing, and KSQL.Responsibilities include platform monitoring, creating key performance metrics, and maintaining cluster health, utilization, and performance.The role involves capacity planning, upgrading hardware/software, and automating administration tasks using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines.Security configurations such as SSL encryption, SASL LDAP authentication, and Kafka ACL-based authorization must be implemented.Hands-on experience in public cloud environments such as Azure, AWS, or GCP is preferred.The candidate should be available for on-call support, shift work, and occasional weekend availability as required.Strong communication, troubleshooting, and documentation skills are necessary, along with the ability to conduct knowledge transfer sessions.Preferred qualifications include Confluent Kafka certification, cloud certifications (e.g., Azure), and experience with microservices, REST APIs, and containerization.Please reach out to me at +919899634637 or jbhatia@forcecraver.com to discuss further.Follow Jitender Bhatia Forcecraver Technologies for more job updates.

This is a 6-month remote contract position, with an urgent need for an offshore resource based in India.Job Title: Java / Kafka ConsultantLocation: Remote in IndiaDuration: 6+ months contractRole Description:The role requires a minimum of four years of experience in setting up Kafka-based big data solutions using Kafka, Spark, and Scala.Strong expertise in Kafka architecture and managing single and multi-node Kafka clusters on VMs, Docker, and Kubernetes is essential.Experience with Confluent Platform is a must, along with a deep understanding of Kafka Producer/Consumer APIs, Stream Processing, and KSQL.Responsibilities include platform monitoring, creating key performance metrics, and maintaining cluster health, utilization, and performance.The role involves capacity planning, upgrading hardware/software, and automating administration tasks using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines.Security configurations such as SSL encryption, SASL LDAP authentication, and Kafka ACL-based authorization must be implemented.Hands-on experience in public cloud environments such as Azure, AWS, or GCP is preferred.The candidate should be available for on-call support, shift work, and occasional weekend availability as required.Strong communication, troubleshooting, and documentation skills are necessary, along with the ability to conduct knowledge transfer sessions.Preferred qualifications include Confluent Kafka certification, cloud certifications (e.g., Azure), and experience with microservices, REST APIs, and containerization.Please reach out to me at +919899634637 or jbhatia@forcecraver.com to discuss further.Follow Jitender Bhatia Forcecraver Technologies for more job updates.

This is a 6-month remote contract position, with an urgent need for an offshore resource based in India.Job Title: Java / Kafka ConsultantLocation: Remote in IndiaDuration: 6+ months contractRole Description:The role requires a minimum of four years of experience in setting up Kafka-based big data solutions using Kafka, Spark, and Scala.Strong expertise in Kafka architecture and managing single and multi-node Kafka clusters on VMs, Docker, and Kubernetes is essential.Experience with Confluent Platform is a must, along with a deep understanding of Kafka Producer/Consumer APIs, Stream Processing, and KSQL.Responsibilities include platform monitoring, creating key performance metrics, and maintaining cluster health, utilization, and performance.The role involves capacity planning, upgrading hardware/software, and automating administration tasks using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines.Security configurations such as SSL encryption, SASL LDAP authentication, and Kafka ACL-based authorization must be implemented.Hands-on experience in public cloud environments such as Azure, AWS, or GCP is preferred.The candidate should be available for on-call support, shift work, and occasional weekend availability as required.Strong communication, troubleshooting, and documentation skills are necessary, along with the ability to conduct knowledge transfer sessions.Preferred qualifications include Confluent Kafka certification, cloud certifications (e.g., Azure), and experience with microservices, REST APIs, and containerization.Please reach out to me at +919899634637 or jbhatia@forcecraver.com to discuss further.Follow Jitender Bhatia Forcecraver Technologies for more job updates.

Let's talk about this topic, guys! Java 24 is pushing the boundaries of performance computing, and one of the most exciting updates is the Vector API (7th Incubator).1. The Vector API allows Java to leverage SIMD - Single Instruction, Multiple Data, enabling parallel execution of mathematical operations. 2. Java can handle vectorized computations efficiently without needing external libraries.3. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Remote jobs could be the next big thing in filling the gap left by the 𝗨𝗦𝗔𝗜𝗗 shutdown, especially in refugee settings like Kakuma. When aid disappears, so do the basic services we rely on. But remote work offers a new kind of lifeline one that’s not based on charity, but on opportunity.At StepUp.One, our mission is to reskill and employ 1 million refugees by 2030. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. We can learn, work, and grow from right here, creating sustainable futures for ourselves and our communities.What role do you think remote work could play in solving long-term challenges in refugee camps?Learn more: https://lnkd.in/dCVTixePhashtag#RemoteWorkForRefugees hashtag#StepUpForChange hashtag#1MillionBy2030

Let's talk about this topic, guys! Java 24 is pushing the boundaries of performance computing, and one of the most exciting updates is the Vector API (7th Incubator).1. The Vector API allows Java to leverage SIMD - Single Instruction, Multiple Data, enabling parallel execution of mathematical operations. 2. Java can handle vectorized computations efficiently without needing external libraries.3. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Remote jobs could be the next big thing in filling the gap left by the 𝗨𝗦𝗔𝗜𝗗 shutdown, especially in refugee settings like Kakuma. When aid disappears, so do the basic services we rely on. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Remote jobs could be the next big thing in filling the gap left by the 𝗨𝗦𝗔𝗜𝗗 shutdown, especially in refugee settings like Kakuma. When aid disappears, so do the basic services we rely on. But remote work offers a new kind of lifeline one that’s not based on charity, but on opportunity.At StepUp.One, our mission is to reskill and employ 1 million refugees by 2030. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

But remote work offers a new kind of lifeline one that’s not based on charity, but on opportunity.At StepUp.One, our mission is to reskill and employ 1 million refugees by 2030. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. We can learn, work, and grow from right here, creating sustainable futures for ourselves and our communities.What role do you think remote work could play in solving long-term challenges in refugee camps?Learn more: https://lnkd.in/dCVTixePhashtag#RemoteWorkForRefugees hashtag#StepUpForChange hashtag#1MillionBy2030

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵



…more

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Remote jobs could be the next big thing in filling the gap left by the 𝗨𝗦𝗔𝗜𝗗 shutdown, especially in refugee settings like Kakuma. When aid disappears, so do the basic services we rely on. But remote work offers a new kind of lifeline one that’s not based on charity, but on opportunity.At StepUp.One, our mission is to reskill and employ 1 million refugees by 2030. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Remote jobs could be the next big thing in filling the gap left by the 𝗨𝗦𝗔𝗜𝗗 shutdown, especially in refugee settings like Kakuma. When aid disappears, so do the basic services we rely on. But remote work offers a new kind of lifeline one that’s not based on charity, but on opportunity.At StepUp.One, our mission is to reskill and employ 1 million refugees by 2030. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵



…more

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Remote jobs could be the next big thing in filling the gap left by the 𝗨𝗦𝗔𝗜𝗗 shutdown, especially in refugee settings like Kakuma. When aid disappears, so do the basic services we rely on. But remote work offers a new kind of lifeline one that’s not based on charity, but on opportunity.At StepUp.One, our mission is to reskill and employ 1 million refugees by 2030. We believe the future isn't just about receiving help, but about becoming capable of helping ourselves. Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. This is a 6-month remote contract position, with an urgent need for an offshore resource based in India.Job Title: Java / Kafka ConsultantLocation: Remote in IndiaDuration: 6+ months contractRole Description:The role requires a minimum of four years of experience in setting up Kafka-based big data solutions using Kafka, Spark, and Scala.Strong expertise in Kafka architecture and managing single and multi-node Kafka clusters on VMs, Docker, and Kubernetes is essential.Experience with Confluent Platform is a must, along with a deep understanding of Kafka Producer/Consumer APIs, Stream Processing, and KSQL.Responsibilities include platform monitoring, creating key performance metrics, and maintaining cluster health, utilization, and performance.The role involves capacity planning, upgrading hardware/software, and automating administration tasks using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines.Security configurations such as SSL encryption, SASL LDAP authentication, and Kafka ACL-based authorization must be implemented.Hands-on experience in public cloud environments such as Azure, AWS, or GCP is preferred.The candidate should be available for on-call support, shift work, and occasional weekend availability as required.Strong communication, troubleshooting, and documentation skills are necessary, along with the ability to conduct knowledge transfer sessions.Preferred qualifications include Confluent Kafka certification, cloud certifications (e.g., Azure), and experience with microservices, REST APIs, and containerization.Please reach out to me at +919899634637 or jbhatia@forcecraver.com to discuss further.Follow Jitender Bhatia Forcecraver Technologies for more job updates.

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

Through remote work, refugees can connect with global clients, earn a living, and gain dignity, not just survive, but thrive.Remote jobs mean we don’t have to wait for aid to come back. Let's talk about this topic, guys! Java 24 is pushing the boundaries of performance computing, and one of the most exciting updates is the Vector API (7th Incubator).1. The Vector API allows Java to leverage SIMD - Single Instruction, Multiple Data, enabling parallel execution of mathematical operations. 2. Java can handle vectorized computations efficiently without needing external libraries.3. I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup

I’ve been building software with hashtag#Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.Why?Because Java isn’t going anywhere.Yet people still say it’s outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too “enterprisey.”Wrong.Java quietly powers much of the real world.From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.It’s everywhere.Why?Because Java works!It’s stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.And with every new release, it’s getting better.Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:✔️ Streamlined syntax →  A “Hello, World!” now takes just a few lines of code.✔️ Pattern matching for primitives → Cleaner logic with less clutter.✔️ Markdown for JavaDocs → Documentation that doesn’t make your eyes bleed.✔️ Immutable records + sealed classes → Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.What about AI?Well, sure, hashtag#Python dominates ML/DL/AI.But when it’s time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.Take Uber’s Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don’t have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It’s simply harder to make a mess.And that discipline? Could sometimes make a difference 🍵

🗑 Soft. Weak. Phantom… The ruthless GC in Java! 🚀When the JVM decides your object is no longer needed, it launches a powerful combo:🔍 MARK – methodically traverses all accessible objects and marks the ones still alive.🗑 SWEEP – mercilessly sends everything unmarked into oblivion.But what kinds of references exist in Java?🔗 StrongReference – “I’ll never let go!” As long as at least one strong reference exists, GC won’t touch the object.💪 SoftReference – “GC, not now, please…” The object is removed only if memory is running low.💨 WeakReference – “Goodbye, no hard feelings.” GC removes it at the first opportunity.👻 PhantomReference – “I’m gone, but still here…” The object is deleted, but you can track when it happens.And now, what’s new in GC?🔥 CMS GC – removed (Java 14). Everything that was "Concurrent" and "Mark-Sweep" is now history.🚀 G1 GC – now turbo-smart (Java 20). Optimized thread handling makes object removal even faster.⚡ ZGC – now understands object aging (Java 21). It manages both young and old generations – meaning your objects disappear even more efficiently!📈 Java 17 – +8.66% performance boost compared to Java 11. Higher speed, and an even more ruthless GC.So hold on tight to your objects – because GC is now faster, smarter, and more merciless than ever! 😆hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollector hashtag#G1GC hashtag#ZGC hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#GCMemoryCleanup
